title: Who will win the U.S. Senate election for Iowa in 2020?
preds: Favorite commentator comment ...but never ask her anything about Soy Beans (she has a lot to say about them.)
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/senate/iowa/ Note to self: again, is the right strategy to remain overweight Greenfield or to match 538 at 50%?
The race has tightened but Democrats have a slight edge
Joni Ernst is very popular.  Farm grants, increased agricultural trade.

..Race seems to be a toss-up  FWIW, Dems reportedly have somewhat more early voters than Republicans: https://iowastartingline.com/2020/10/31/iowas-best-early-voting-counties-for-each-party-three-days-out/ ..Election Day Iowa weather forecast is mild: https://weather.com/weather/tenday/l/Des+Moines+IA ..COVID-19 ramifications could be a concern for in-person voters. 538 gives Greenfield the slight edge. But Iowa polling bias was fairly large in 2016 and Trump did better than expected. I've seen some evidence that polling bias has been similar in recent years so operating under that idea I'll give Ernst the very slight edge. Bias could easily be different this time around.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/senate/iowa/ Also: Des Moines Register newspaper has now endorsed Dem. Greenfield

Assuming that Trump is going to win Iowa in the presidential race, I don't see how can we have a split ticket here. Ernst has kept pretty close to Trump. Hard to see many voters going for Trump but not for Ernst. If Biden wins Iowa, that's another matter. So my forecast reflects the chance of Biden (and Greenfield) winning there.
Last poll that had Republican candidate Ernst ahead was more than a month ago. 10 polls after that show Democrats to be ahead. Increasing the chances of Democrats
Ernst -1 for not knowing the price of soybeans. Ernst -2 for not knowing the price of corn. Ernst -3 for the DJT-shaped anchor currently weighing her down.

Green field's lead in the summer is still holding.
Yes I am all over the place on this one. Most polling gives slight edge to Greenfield.
The race is a toss-up according to 538 and the cook report.
Trump is dragging Ernst down and polls show the democrat pulling away here.

FWIW, '538' website recent forecast + other current analysis: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/senate/iowa/ https://www.270towin.com/2020-senate-polls/iowa/ https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/13/politics/election-2020-senate-race-rankings-three-weeks/index.html https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/12/politics/iowa-senate-race-joni-ernst/index.html

Ernst continues to tie herself to Trump in a bid to regain the lead and maintain her support in certain regions of the state. However, with Trump's wavering support statewide and a nationwide hole that seems to grow by the day it is difficult to say whether or not this strategy will pay off. Ernst is unlikely to gain much support between now and the election given the only clear plan in the Senate is a confirmation hearing that is unpopular amongst Americans, so this will likely come down to who gets more people to show up and vote.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
In 2014 Ernst was maybe 2 points ahead in the polls, it was called a toss up. She won by 8 Points. In 2016 Trump won Iowa by 9 points. Polls are close but state polls are unreliable.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

This race appears to be 'up for grabs'. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/iowa/ https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/joni-ernst-is-now-in-trouble-trump-is-a-huge-part-of-her-problem/2020/09/28/32f7ec62-01c5-11eb-a2db-417cddf4816a_story.htm https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/iowa/

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

The economy is headed down and coronavirus is supposed to have a second wave starting now.  All of this is bad for Ernst as a Trump apologist.   Also, she seems to be doing worse than before in the latest polls, and I doubt the Barrett hearing are going to help her.   Democrats seem to be focused on Barrett's opposition to Roe v Wade and more importantly her perceived opposition to Obamacare.   Democrats could also could make a lot out of the lack of coronavirus stimulus while holding hearings for a wackadoodle supreme court justice appointment, Finally,  in 2018, Iowa tossed out a number of house republicans and replaced them with a democratic majority so a defeat for Ernst is very possible-- and likely.

I tend to default to 538 but make an adjustment by a few percentage points towards the candidate who matches the states partisan lean. My reasoning is that the states 538 miss called in 2018 tended to be democrats in red states. I believe this is because partisanship is at record highs and many models are not fully accounting full this. Ernst is 53% in 538, I will adjust her to 56.

Greenfield has an advantage in virtually all recent polls, Ernst is not a popular candidate, and the presidential is basically a toss up at this point. The incumbency advantage is gone and her recent efforts to win over voters by mounting a weak and toothless defense of Ginsburg's seat shows the hot water she's in. Not a sure thing either way but the momentum is with her opponent at the moment and she has not shown herself capable of stopping the bleeding as of yet.

Increased Greenfield's chances from previous forecast. Recent polling finds her ahead in both a high and low turnout scenario (3% and 1% respectively). Ernst is in favor of filling the Supreme Court seat vacated by RBG. This topic is strong along party lines (Republicans for, Democrats against), but overall soft with the undecided crowd - 51% against filling, 41% approve of filling before the presidential election.  The unfortunate passing of RBG is a bit of a rallying cry amongst democrats, including an increase in financial contributions. ActBlue reported $6.3M in contributions within an hour of RBG's reported passing. This gives democrats momentum moving into the final stages of campaigning.
Inching forecast slightly closer to 538 (website) prediction for now, pending additional polling. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/democrats-are-slight-favorites-to-take-back-the-senate/

+7 to Ernst based on 538 model. Looking at the polls it does look like most of the recent change is based on one unrated poll (there hasn't been much polling recently) so I'll need to update this one soon.
Ernst could be in real trouble. Chances are slight but possible the Dems win here.
Downgraded Greenfield for skipping the first debate, not as much as I normally would have given Ernst's recent comments regarding COVID numbers.
Covid put this seat in play. The covid numbers are coming down and may not be as big a factor unless there is a surge this fall. Cautiously saying Ernst will hang on.
Greenfield (Dem.) showing a small lead in some recent polls: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/iowa/

In 2016 Iowa was Trump country with a 51% Trump to 41% Clinton outcome. Current polls show Trump and Biden almost even (46.6% Trump, 45.3% Biden).  In 2012, Obama captured 52% of the vote to Romney’s 46.2%.  Ernst won her 2014 US Senate election 52.2% to 43.7% to US Rep Bruce Braley, even though polls indicated a much closer race. During her time in Congress, she has voted along the Trump line 91.1% of the time.  What has changed between now and then? In the last two years, the 25,000 voter gap between registered republicans and registered democrats has shrunk. In 2016, Trump had a strong showing with the over 65 voters, current polls show Biden leading Trump by 2 points in this category. Over 65 voters make up about a third of all registered Iowa voters. Older voters are more comfortable with absentee voting given the health risks of in-person polling. https://www.aarp.org/research/topics/politics/info-2020/absentee-voting-iowa.html Greenfield is running with Social Security at the front of her platform. She was a direct recipient of those and Union benefits when her husband died on the job. 20% of Iowans receive some sort of Social Security benefit and 25% of the over 65 population rely on Social Security as their main source of income.  During Ernst’s 2014 election, unemployment was around 4%. Earlier this year due to COVID that number bit 11% before settling down to 8% in June of 2020. https://www.iowaworkforcedevelopment.gov/sites/search.iowaworkforcedevelopment.gov/files/documents/2018/StatusIowaWorkforce06_2020.pdf Both candidates were a part of farm families which will resonate with the voters.  How do third party candidates that look to capture 2% - 3% of the vote impact either candidate? Libertarian Rick Stewart is anti-Social Security so this should not affect Greenfield, however grass-roots independent Suzanne Herzog may garner a fraction of a percent away from Greenfield. This race is close enough in the polls that every percentage point is likely critical.  Iowa looks to flip back to the Democrats.

538 is showing Trump with a 68% chance of carrying the state (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/iowa/). RCP on the other hand is showing that Greenfield is slightly ahead (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/ia/iowa_senate_ernst_vs_greenfield-7072.html). My priors is that polling tends to revert back to the fundamentals which will favor a Republican incumbent in an election year, so I think Ernst is going to take it. Although there is room for that to change.
Polls from 538 are very close. The presidential election leans significantly toward Biden so I'm giving the slight advantage to Greenfield.

Polling now shows a toss-up, despite Ernst being an incumbent for the race. Generally, popular incumbents have a sizeable lead heading into the election, but with margins this close the momentum likely lies with her opponent, Greenfield, who is up in as many polls as she is down, though never clearly outside the margin of error in either scenario. This race will most likely be decided by up-ballot preferences more than incumbent or policy advantages if the current state of affairs holds.

Greenfield has negligible lead in the polls and Iowa has been going republican for some time now. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/ia/iowa_senate_ernst_vs_greenfield-7072.html https://ballotpedia.org/Iowa_State_Senate_elections,_2018
The problem with polls is they have a hard time reaching people and their sample size is small.
Close polling but expect this to swing to GOP as election nears.
The Incumbent is Republican and will be re-elected.
Going out on a limb on this one, I think the tides are turning a little bit in Iowa I seem to have been since 2018

(Initial forecast:) Maybe I missed it but didn't notice forecasters citing recent polls + some other potential factors:  ..Republican Ernst is lately reported with a small polling lead, within the margin of error:  https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/510651-poll-trump-ernst-lead-democratic-challengers-by-3-points-in-iowa https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/iowa/ ..Most 'pundits' are rating this race as a 'toss-up'. https://www.270towin.com/2020-senate-election/consensus-2020-senate-forecast ..Ernst has the considerable advantage of incumbency: 
https://www.opensecrets.org/elections-overview/reelection-rates ..This Iowa senate seat was previously held for 20 years by Democrat Tom Harkin. It's flipped back and forth between parties since 1973.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_senators_from_Iowa ..Recent polls show President Donald Trump with a small lead in Iowa. Ernst has at times spoken favorably of administration actions/positions. https://www.270towin.com/2020-polls-biden-trump/iowa/ https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/02/politics/joni-ernst-trump-ukraine-wrong-manner-comment-cnntv/index.html Forecasting a slight edge for the Republican Ernst mainly based upon the general advantage of incumbency..
The state may flip on this seat knowing they still have Chuck, opening the door for Greenfield to squeak out a narrow victory.
Democrats have the edge here as they have a good candidate to run against Ernst. Polls are tied as of today and anti-Trump sentiment may be enough to tip the scales.
A close race, but I think Iowa is going to pivot back to democrat.
Farmers are angry. Covid. Unemployment. Evictions. Ernst may still pull it out but if this a referendum on Trump she has tied herself close to him and at present his search for optics is backfiring.
Very close, but if there is strong anti-Trump turnout, the Dem may squeak by.  Polls now have the Dem slightly ahead, with neither breaking 50%.

Ernst has the incumbent advantage, which would normally mean she had a large head-start over her opponent. However, her small lead shrank in the past few months and she is now slightly down in the plurality of polls. Her press has not been positive in most major news stories, and the presidential race is a toss-up, so her prospects as an incumbent have completely washed away.
In 2014 the DNC candidate ran a similar race and lost by almost 20 points. This race will be a lot closer but will still be won by Joni Ernst.
